title: Capacitors - Delta V change as distance decreases

content.question: A charged parallel-plate capacitor is isolated from external sources of charge or potential difference. The two plates are moved closer together. What happens to the potential difference <math alttext="delta V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></math> between the plates as they are moved together, and what evidence or reasoning supports the claim?

choices.label: <math alttext="delta V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></math> increases. There is an increase in the attractive force between the plates.
<math alttext="delta V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></math> increases. Work must be done by an external force to push the plates toward each other.
<math alttext="delta V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></math> decreases. The charge on each plate must spread out over a larger area.
<math alttext="delta V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></math> decreases. The electric field remains constant and the plate separation decreases.

content.answer: <math alttext="delta V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></math> decreases. The electric field remains constant and the plate separation decreases.
